questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol 3 days ago, presented with irritability, altered sensorium, and visual hallucinations. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Delirium Tremens

 

Delirium Tremens (DT) is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that typically occurs 48-72 hours after the last drink. It is characterized by:

 

  • Autonomic instability (e.g., tachycardia, hypertension, hyperthermia)
  • Severe agitation and irritability
  • Altered sensorium (e.g., confusion, delirium)
  • Visual and auditory hallucinations

 

DT is a medical emergency with high morbidity and mortality if not treated promptly.

 

The treatment of choice is benzodiazepines, which help to control agitation and prevent complications such as seizures. Long-acting benzodiazepines like diazepam are preferred unless there is liver dysfunction, in which case shorter-acting agents like lorazepam or oxazepam are used.

 

Special Considerations for Liver Impairment:

 

  • Cirrhosis or Severe Liver Failure: In patients with compromised liver function, the metabolism of drugs, particularly those processed by the liver, can be significantly impaired.
  • Short-Acting Drugs: Lorazepam is recommended as it is less reliant on hepatic oxidation and more on glucuronidation, which is relatively preserved in liver disease.
  • Oxazepam is also suggested as it undergoes direct conjugation in the liver without the need for extensive metabolism, making it safer for patients with severe liver impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke’s Encephalopathy: Wernicke’s Encephalopathy is caused by thiamine deficiency and presents with a triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and confusion. It does not typically present with hallucinations or irritability.

 

Option C. Korsakoff Psychosis: Korsakoff Psychosis is a chronic condition resulting from untreated Wernicke’s Encephalopathy, characterized by severe memory impairment/ amnesia and confabulation. It does not present acutely and lacks the autonomic instability seen in DT.

 

Option D. Alcohol Withdrawal Seizures: Alcohol withdrawal seizures typically occur within 6-48 hours after the last drink and present as generalized tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS). They do not present with the prolonged altered sensorium or hallucinations characteristic of DT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delirium Tremens is a severe alcohol withdrawal syndrome occurring 48-72 hours after cessation of alcohol intake, characterized by autonomic instability, severe agitation, altered sensorium, and hallucinations. It requires immediate treatment with benzodiazepines to manage symptoms and prevent complications.

questions.text: Maternal antibodies do not provide significant immunity in a neonate against: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Polio

 

While infants can acquire polio antibodies from their mothers, this immunity is not consistent and can fade during infancy. Therefore, newborns are given a 0 dose of polio drops to ensure protection against the virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetanus: Maternal antibodies against tetanus can provide significant immunity to the newborn. Pregnant women are advised to receive the Tdap vaccine during each pregnancy, ideally between 27-36 weeks of gestation. Maternal antibodies produced from the vaccine can protect the newborn against tetanus.

 

Option C. Diphtheria: Maternal antibodies provide some protection, but it's less reliable than tetanus


Protection duration is shorter (1-2 months)

 

Option D. Measles: Maternal antibodies help protect the baby from measles until about 9 months of age. After that, the efficacy of maternal antibodies decreases, which is why the measles vaccine is given at 9 months of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maternal antibodies do not provide consistent and lasting immunity against polio in neonates, necessitating early vaccination with polio drops.

questions.text: In indirect inguinal hernia surgery, which nerve is most commonly injured? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Genitofemoral

 

In the context of Lichtenstein's hernia repair, which is an open mesh repair for inguinal hernias, the ilioinguinal nerve is the most likely to be injured, it was not listed as an option in this question. Therefore, the genitofemoral nerve is the best answer among the given choices.

 

This is because the genitofemoral nerve runs within the spermatic cord, which can be manipulated during the surgery. During the separation of the hernia sac from the spermatic cord, there is a risk of injuring the genitofemoral nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral: The femoral nerve is too large and lies deeper within the body, making it less likely to be injured during an inguinal hernia repair.

 

Option C. Obturator: The obturator nerve is not typically associated with inguinal hernia anatomy and is not at risk during these surgeries.

 

Option D. Pudendal: The pudendal nerve is related to the pelvic region and is not typically involved in the anatomy of an inguinal hernia repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In open inguinal hernia repairs, particularly Lichtenstein's hernia repair, the ilioinguinal nerve >> genitofemoral nerve is at risk of injury due to its location within the spermatic cord and very rarely iliohypogastric nerve can be injured.

 

In laparoscopic hernia repair, there is a risk of injuring nerves such as the lateral cutaneous nerve, anterior cutaneous nerve, and femoral nerve.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient happens to have pellagra-like eruptions on skin in spring season from the last 5 years with normal HIAA and high aminoaciduria. Indole levels in urine are normal. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hartnup disease

 

Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a defect in the absorption of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids in the intestine and renal tubules. This defect leads to increased excretion of amino acids in the urine, known as aminoaciduria. Tryptophan is a precursor for niacin (Vitamin B3) synthesis, and its deficiency can lead to pellagra-like symptoms, including dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, often referred to as the "3 D's" of pellagra.

 

In this case, the patient presents with pellagra-like eruptions and high aminoaciduria. The normal HIAA levels rule out a carcinoid tumor, which would show elevated levels of 5-HIAA in the urine due to increased serotonin production. The absence of dietary history indicative of niacin or tryptophan deficiency (as seen in nutritional pellagra) further supports Hartnup disease as the diagnosis. Additionally, essential fructosuria is a benign condition and does not cause skin eruptions or pellagra-like symptoms.

 

Note –

 

  • Tryptophan is an aromatic amino acid with a bulky indole ring side chain.
  • 60 mg of tryptophan converts into 1 mg of niacin
  • Best Treatment of Niacin deficiency - Niacin or nicotinamide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoid tumor: Carcinoid syndrome would typically present with elevated levels of 5-HIAA in the urine due to excessive conversion of tryptophan to serotonin. The normal HIAA levels in this patient make carcinoid tumor an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Option B. Nutritional pellagra: This condition is due to a dietary deficiency of niacin (Vitamin B3) or its precursor tryptophan. However, the patient does not present with a history of dietary deficiency, and the high aminoaciduria suggests an alternative diagnosis.

 

Option D. Essential fructosuria: This condition is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme fructokinase, leading to fructose excretion in urine. However, it is asymptomatic and does not cause skin eruptions or any pellagra-like symptoms, making it an incorrect answer in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra or pellagra like symptoms can result from (Differential Diagnosis):

 

  • Niacin (B3) deficiency due to a diet high in maize, which is low in tryptophan.
  • Vitamin B6 deficiency, since the enzyme kynureninase, which catalyzes a step in niacin synthesis from tryptophan, requires B6 as a cofactor. B6 deficiency also leads to increased synthesis of xanthurenic acid
  • Carcinoid syndrome: can be differentiated with elevated HIAA level with pellagra like symptoms.
  • Hartnup disease can present with pellagra-like symptoms due to defective absorption of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids, leading to high aminoaciduria and niacin deficiency.

choices.text: Bath the baby with warm water immediately

questions.text: A mother delivers a 2.5 kg baby with normal vaginal delivery in a rural area. Which of the following is an incorrect statement? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bath the baby with warm water immediately

     

Newborn care practices emphasize immediate and appropriate actions to ensure the health and safety of the infant. Bathing the baby immediately after birth is discouraged because the baby's skin needs to adapt to the new environment, and the vernix (a protective layer on the skin) should be allowed to remain on the skin for as long as possible to provide a barrier against infection. Immediate bathing can lead to hypothermia and is generally not recommended, especially in settings where environmental conditions (such as warmth and cleanliness) are not optimal.

 

The recommended practice is to wait at least 24 hours and then start with gentle sponging until the umbilical cord falls off, typically within the first week of life. Only after this can full baths be introduced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exclusive breastfeeding: This is the recommended feeding method for newborns, providing optimal nutrition and immunity support. It should be started within the first hour of birth.

 

Option C. Clean the eyes: Cleaning the eyes is a standard neonatal practice to prevent infection. This is part of routine newborn care and helps prevent neonatal conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Skin to skin contact: Skin-to-skin contact is encouraged immediately after birth as it helps regulate the newborn's body temperature, promotes bonding, and supports breastfeeding initiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bathing a newborn immediately after birth is not recommended; it should be delayed until the umbilical cord falls off, and gentle sponging should be started after 24 hours to maintain hygiene and prevent hypothermia.

questions.text: In a village, it is observed that several farmers have crossed gait and use a stick for support to stand up and walk. Due to poor yield from farms, they consume meals containing rice and pulses only. Supplementing their diet with which of the following vitamins could have prevented this? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Vitamin C

 

The given clinical scenario points to diagnosis of neurolathyrism. Vitamin C is beneficial in cases of lathyrism.

 

Lathyrism is of two types:

 

  • Neurolathyrism: In human beings

  • Osteolathyrism (Odoratism): In animals

     

Neurolathyrism is caused by eating the pulse ‘Khesari Dal (Lathyrus sativus)’. Diets containing over 30% of this dal consumed over a period of 2 - 6 months result in neurolathyrism

 

Toxin: present in lathyrus seeds is ‘Beta oxalyl amino alanine’ (BOAA)

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old married woman came for an infertility evaluation. On performing further investigations, intramural fibroids of sizes 7x5cm and 5x3cm were seen at the right and left cornual ends of the uterus. Her husband's semen analysis was found to be normal. What is the appropriate management of this case? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laparoscopic Myomectomy

 

Laparoscopic Myomectomy:

 

  • Indications for myomectomy in a woman with infertility and fibroid uterus include:
    • Submucous fibroids of any size/location as they interfere with fertility and pregnancy outcomes.
    • Intramural fibroids that:
      • Distort the endometrial cavity.
      • Are larger than 5 cm in size.
  • In this case, the patient has significant intramural fibroids (7x5 cm and 5x3 cm), making laparoscopic myomectomy the appropriate management to improve fertility outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine artery embolization: This procedure is not indicated for women who wish to conceive as it can compromise uterine function and future fertility.

 

Option C. Artificial reproductive techniques: While ART could be considered in cases of bilateral tubal block, myomectomy should be done prior to potentially relieve the tubal block, improve ART outcomes, and enhance pregnancy outcomes.

 

Option D. GnRH analogues: GnRH analogues are not suitable for this patient as she is eager to conceive. These are typically used for temporary symptom relief or to shrink fibroids preoperatively, but not as a primary treatment for infertility in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopic myomectomy is indicated for intramural fibroids larger than 5 cm in women with infertility, as it can improve fertility and pregnancy outcomes.

 

Ref: Page no 232, DC Dutta’s textbook of gynecology, 8th edition

questions.text: During an ocular examination, the ophthalmologist observes the presence of the shifting fluid sign in the patient. This finding suggests that the patient might have which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Exudative RD

 

  • Shifting fluid is a hallmark feature of serous or exudative retinal detachment.
  • In serous retinal detachment, there is subretinal accumulation of serous fluid mostly due to breakdown in blood-retinal barrier.
  • Fluid shifts to the dependent portion when head position is altered.
  • Serous retinal detachment has a smooth convex configuration and lacks a retinal tear or preretinal traction.
  • Rhegmatogenous RD presents with tobacco dust in anterior vitreous, substantial vitreous blood or inflammatory cells, and retinal breaks.
  • Traction RD has a concave configuration, absent breaks, and severely reduced retinal mobility.
  • Shifting fluid is absent in traction RD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Traction RD: Tractional retinal detachment is caused by fibrovascular proliferation and contraction of epiretinal membranes, leading to mechanical traction on the retina. It has a concave configuration and lacks shifting fluid due to the tethering of the retina by fibrous tissue. Retinal mobility is severely reduced, and retinal breaks are usually absent.

 

Option C. Rhegmatogenous RD: Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment occurs due to a retinal tear or hole that allows vitreous fluid to enter the subretinal space. It presents with signs such as tobacco dust (Shafer's sign) in the anterior vitreous, substantial vitreous blood, inflammatory cells, and visible retinal breaks. Shifting fluid is not a characteristic feature of rhegmatogenous RD.

 

Option D. Retinal Dialysis: Retinal dialysis is a type of retinal tear that typically occurs at the ora serrata, where the retina is particularly thin and prone to tearing. It is most often seen in younger patients or those who have experienced trauma. Shifting fluid is not a specific feature of retinal dialysis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which channel opens when action potential begins? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Na+ influx

 

The initiation of an action potential in a neuron begins with the opening of voltage-gated sodium (Na+) channels. When a neuron receives a sufficient threshold stimulus, these sodium channels open, allowing Na+ ions to flow into the cell. This influx of positive sodium ions causes the membrane potential to become more positive, a process known as depolarization.

 

Depolarization is the first phase of the action potential, which is essential for the propagation of electrical signals along the neuron. Following depolarization, the action potential continues with other ion movements that facilitate the signal's transmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cl- influx: Chloride ions typically move into the cell during inhibitory postsynaptic potentials, causing hyperpolarization (making the inside of the cell more negative). This is not related to the initiation of action potentials.

 

Option C. K+ efflux: Potassium efflux occurs during the repolarization phase of the action potential, not at the beginning. Repolarization helps restore the resting membrane potential after depolarization.

 

Option D. Ca2+ influx: Calcium influx is crucial in various cellular processes, such as neurotransmitter release at synapses. However, it is not involved in the initial depolarization phase of the action potential.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initiation of an action potential in a neuron is marked by the opening of voltage-gated sodium (Na+) channels, leading to Na+ influx and membrane depolarization.

questions.text: Which of the following are vitamin K dependent factors requiring gamma carboxylation? (NEETPG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 7, 9, 10

 

Vitamin K is essential for the post-translational modification of certain proteins required for blood coagulation. This modification is gamma carboxylation, which allows these proteins to bind calcium ions and participate effectively in the coagulation cascade.

 

Vitamin K Dependent Factors:

 

  • Procoagulants: Factors II (prothrombin), VII, IX, and X.
  • Anticoagulants: Protein C and Protein S.

 

These factors are synthesized in the liver and require gamma carboxylation of specific glutamic acid residues for their activity. Without this modification, they cannot bind calcium effectively, which is necessary for their role in coagulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin K dependent factors are procoagulants (factors 2,7,9,10) and anticoagulants (protein C and S). They require gamma carboxylation for their activity.

questions.text: Which disease the girl is related to and what's her name? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Sapna, Leprosy


The girl in the image is named Sapna, and she is associated with the National Leprosy Eradication Program. Sapna is an emblematic figure used to raise awareness about leprosy prevention and control through information, education, and communication (IEC) strategies. She symbolizes the message that leprosy is completely curable. Sapna herself is portrayed as a former leprosy patient who has been fully cured, aiming to reduce stigma and educate the public about the disease's curability.

 

National Leprosy Mission Trust of India is the agency who came out with the concept of the girl Sapna for Leprosy Awareness Efforts Generation.

 

Educational Objective:


Sapna is a character created to promote leprosy awareness and emphasize that leprosy is a 100% curable disease.

choices.text: Intracellular fluid
Extracellular fluid

questions.text: A body fluid sample is being studied and has Na: 10 mEq/L, K: 140 mEq/L, CI: 4 mE/L. Identify the compartment from which the sample has been obtained? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intracellular fluid

 

Explanation

 

The electrolyte composition in the sample obtained has high concentration of potassium, suggests that it is intracellular fluid (IC) compartment.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial and Option C. Extracellular Fluid generally have higher sodium and chloride concentrations and much lower potassium concentrations.

 

Option D. Plasma, part of the extracellular fluid, would similarly show higher sodium and chloride but lower potassium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The composition of potassium, sodium, and chloride in the sample aligns with that typically found in intracellular fluid, reflecting its origin from within cells, where potassium is the major cation, unlike extracellular compartments dominated by sodium and chloride.

questions.text: Which of the following can be mediated by CRISPR CAS 9 technology? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DNA editing

 

CRISPR-Cas9 technology is a powerful tool used for DNA editing. It works by creating double-strand breaks in the DNA at specific locations. The CRISPR (Clustered Regularly Interspersed Short Palindromic Repeats) component guides the Cas9 endonuclease to the precise cutting site within the genome. Once the DNA is cut, the cell’s natural repair mechanisms are used to add, delete, or replace genetic material at the targeted site, enabling precise editing of the DNA sequence.

 

CRISPR-Cas9 is derived from a natural immune system in bacteria, which uses this mechanism to defend against bacteriophages by cutting their DNA. In genetic engineering, this system has been harnessed for various applications, including gene deletion, exogenous gene insertion, and multigene editing, all of which involve altering the DNA sequence in a targeted manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA replication: CRISPR-Cas9 does not play a role in DNA replication, which is the process by which DNA is copied before cell division. DNA replication is managed by other cellular machinery, including DNA polymerases.

 

Option B. Post-transcriptional modification: This involves changes to RNA after it has been transcribed from DNA, such as splicing, editing, or polyadenylation. CRISPR-Cas9 does not mediate these processes; it specifically targets DNA.

 

Option C. DNA induction: This term is not commonly used in the context of molecular biology, and it does not apply to CRISPR-Cas9 technology. CRISPR-Cas9 is specifically used for editing DNA, not for inducing or initiating processes within the DNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRISPR-Cas9 technology is primarily used for precise DNA editing, enabling targeted modifications to the genetic code

questions.text: A baby presented with abdominal pain. On examination, a mass is palpated in the right lumbar region. A barium enema is done, and the image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intussusception

 

Intussusception is a condition where a portion of the bowel is telescoped into an adjacent segment, with the apex of the intussusceptum being more prone to ischemia which leads to gangrene. The most common location of intussusception is ileocolic. It is commonly seen in infants during the weaning period following the introduction of new food, vaccination, or upper respiratory tract infection. The currently approved rotavirus vaccines are associated with very minimal risk of intussusception. An area of enlarged submucosal Peyer's patch acts as a lead point for intussusception.

 

The clinical scenario of pain abdomen with a palpable mass in the right lumbar region along with the barium enema showing claw sign is suggestive of intussusception. Some lead points in children are Meckel's diverticulum, intestinal polyp, inflamed appendix, submucosal hemorrhage seen in Henoch-Schonlein purpura, and intestinal duplication cysts. Patients usually present with cramping abdominal pain, palpable sausage-shaped abdominal mass, vomiting, and passage of red currant jelly stools.

 

Diagnosis is confirmed by abdominal ultrasound which shows the target sign bull's eye sign and pseudokidney sign. Management of intussusception includes prompt referral to a pediatric surgeon for reduction by air or contrast enema or surgical intervention if there is a failure of non-operative reduction or clinical instability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Volvulus: Volvulus, specifically sigmoid volvulus, shows a characteristic "coffee bean" sign on imaging. It involves the twisting of the intestine around itself, which can lead to obstruction and ischemia but presents differently on imaging.

 

Option C. Duodenal Atresia: Duodenal atresia typically presents with a "double bubble" sign on imaging, which results from the dilatation of the stomach and proximal duodenum. This condition leads to bilious vomiting and is evident soon after birth.

 

Option D. Intestinal Obstruction: General intestinal obstruction shows multiple air-fluid levels on imaging, which is different from the claw sign seen in intussusception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intussusception presents with cramping abdominal pain, palpable mass, and red currant jelly stools, and is confirmed by imaging showing the claw sign.

questions.text: Anterior ethmoidal sinus drains into: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Middle meatus

 

The anterior ethmoidal sinus, along with the maxillary sinus and frontal sinus, drains into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity. The middle meatus is a crucial drainage pathway for these sinuses, allowing mucus to flow from the sinuses into the nasal cavity. This drainage is essential for maintaining sinus health and preventing infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inferior meatus: This meatus primarily serves as the drainage site for the nasolacrimal duct, not the ethmoidal sinuses.

 

Option C. Superior meatus: The superior meatus is the drainage site for the posterior ethmoidal sinus.

 

Option D. Nasal cavity: This is a general term and does not specify the precise drainage pathway for the anterior ethmoidal sinus, which specifically drains into the middle meatus.

 

Additionally, the sphenoid sinuses drain into the sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior ethmoidal sinus, along with the maxillary and frontal sinuses, drains into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented in OPD with a swelling that has been slowly growing in the past 2 years. On examination, it was variable in consistency and mobile. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parotid tumor

 

  • The given clinical scenario and image points to a diagnosis of parotid tumor.
  • MC benign parotid tumor is Pleomorphic Adenoma.
  • MC site: superficial lobe of parotid

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermoid cyst: Seen in children at lines of mesodermal fusion like outer canthus of eye.

 

 

Option C. Sebaceous cyst: Will show soft consistency and punctum.

 

 

Option D. Swollen cervical lymph node – will show firm consistency.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A parotid tumor, particularly pleomorphic adenoma, is the most common benign tumor of the parotid gland.
  • It is characterized by slow growth, a variable consistency, and mobility, commonly found in the superficial lobe of the parotid gland.
  • Proper diagnosis involves imaging and FNAC, with treatment typically involving surgical removal while preserving the facial nerve if possible.

questions.text: Identify the inappropriate drug dosage of leprosy medications in adults among the following options? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rifampicin 450 mg weekly

 

In adults with leprosy, rifampicin should be given as 600mg ONCE MONTHLY, not 450mg weekly. The correct dosing regimen for adults includes:

 

  • Rifampicin: 600mg once monthly (supervised)
  • Dapsone: 100mg daily
  • Clofazimine: 300mg once monthly (supervised) + 50mg daily
  • Clofazimine dosage is half of rifampicin for monthly dose (300mg) and half of dapsone for daily dose (50mg)
  • The dose of 450 mg once a month is typically reserved for children weighing less than 35 kg.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clofazimine 300 mg once a month

 

  • Correct supervised monthly dose
  • Equal to half the monthly rifampicin dose

 

Option B. Clofazimine 50 mg daily

 

  • Correct daily unsupervised dose
  • Equal to half the daily dapsone dose

 

Option D. Dapsone 100 mg daily

 

  • Correct daily unsupervised dose
  • Standard component of both PB and MB regimens
  • Well-established dosage

 

 

WHO Regimen

 

 

 

Educational Objective:


In adult leprosy treatment, rifampicin is given as 600mg once monthly (supervised dose), not 450mg weekly.

questions.text: Which of the following anatomical landmarks is not commonly used for identifying the facial nerve trunk during parotid surgery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inferior belly of omohyoid muscle

 

The omohyoid muscle is a thin, flat muscle in the anterior neck, and it has no direct anatomical relation to the facial nerve trunk. Therefore, it is not used as a landmark to identify the facial nerve trunk during surgeries.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrograde dissection from distal branch: This involves tracing the facial nerve branches from their more distal and superficial positions back towards their origin at the main trunk of the facial nerve. This is a common technique used by surgeons, especially when there is difficulty locating the main trunk due to factors like inflammation, previous surgery, or anatomical variations.

 

Option B. Tragal pointer: It is a small cartilaginous projection at the anterior margin of the external auditory meatus, from the tragus of the ear. The main trunk of the facial nerve typically lies about 1 cm deep and slightly inferior to the tragal pointer, making it a reliable landmark to locate the facial nerve trunk during parotid gland surgeries.

 

Option D. Posterior belly of digastric: The posterior belly of the digastric muscle is another important anatomical landmark in parotid surgeries. The main trunk of the facial nerve is usually found superficial and medial to the posterior belly of the digastric muscle. This muscle serves as a consistent landmark to help in locating the facial nerve trunk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methods to identify the facial nerve trunk during parotid surgeries:

questions.text: A patient presents with post-auricular numbness and a thickened cord-like structure in the cervical region. Identify the most likely structure involved: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Greater auricular nerve

 

The greater auricular nerve (C2, C3) branch of the cervical plexus is the most likely structure involved in this case. The symptoms described - post-auricular numbness and a thickened cord-like structure - are characteristic of great auricular nerve involvement. This nerve has two important divisions:

 

  • Anterior division: supplies the angle of the mandible (shaving area)
  • Posterior division: supplies the auricle (pinna) The nerve runs towards the ear/pinna and is responsible for sensory innervation of this region. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. External jugular vein: Incorrect. This vein is located superficially in the cervical region, but its pathology, such as thrombosis, typically presents with redness, swelling, and engorgement. 

 

Option B. Cervical lymph nodes: Incorrect. Enlarged or inflamed lymph nodes are usually nodular and can cause tenderness but not numbness unless compressing a nearby nerve. 

 

Option C. Superficial thrombophlebitis: Incorrect. This condition involves inflammation of superficial veins and is characterized by redness, pain, and warmth along the course of the vein. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The greater auricular nerve (C2, C3) provides sensory innervation to the skin over the parotid region, auricle, and angle of the mandible. Lesions or compression of this nerve can lead to post-auricular numbness and symptoms along its anatomical path.

questions.text: A woman on anti-depressants presents with bleeding. She gives a history of bulky stools which sticks to the pan. Which of the following vitamin deficiency can cause bleeding in this condition?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin K

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K is essential for blood clotting, and its deficiency can lead to a bleeding tendency. Bulky stools that stick to the pan can be indicative of malabsorption issues, which could result in inadequate absorption of fat-soluble vitamins, including Vitamin K. This deficiency can lead to bleeding problems.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency is not typically associated with bleeding disorders but can lead to other health issues, including vision problems.

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency can result in various symptoms, but it is not known to directly cause bleeding disorders.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency may lead to neurological and muscle problems but is not a common cause of bleeding disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulky, greasy stools that stick to the pan (often described as "steatorrhea") can be indicative of malabsorption, a condition where the absorption of nutrients, including fat-soluble vitamins, is impaired. Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin crucial for the synthesis of blood clotting factors in the liver. Deficiency of vitamin K can lead to impaired blood clotting and a tendency to bleed.

 

Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin crucial for the synthesis of blood clotting factors in the liver. Deficiency of vitamin K can lead to impaired blood clotting and a tendency to bleed.Top of Form

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 532

questions.text: During examination of a patient with an intern, the professor asks the patient to invert his foot and he points at the prominent tendon behind the medial malleolus. Which is the tendon being pointed at here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tibialis posterior

 

The tendon behind the medial malleolus that becomes prominent when the foot is inverted is the tibialis posterior tendon. This tendon plays a key role in foot inversion and is located just behind the medial malleolus, making it palpable during this maneuver. It functions to support the arch of the foot and assists in the inversion of the foot, which matches the scenario described in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tibialis anterior: This tendon is located on the front of the ankle and is responsible for dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot but is not located behind the medial malleolus. Hence, it is not the tendon being pointed at in this scenario.

 

Option C. Extensor digitorum: This tendon is responsible for extending the toes and dorsiflexing the foot. It is located on the dorsum of the foot, not behind the medial malleolus, and does not become prominent during inversion.

 

Option D. Extensor hallucis longus: This tendon is involved in extending the big toe and dorsiflexing the foot. It is positioned on the dorsum of the foot, not behind the medial malleolus, and does not become prominent with foot inversion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tibialis posterior tendon is located behind the medial malleolus and is most prominent when the foot is inverted. This anatomical detail is essential for identifying the tendon during a physical examination.

questions.text: A 56-year-old chronic smoker presented with complaints of weight loss and cough for more than 1 year. He also has hypercalcemia. His biopsy report revealed hyperchromatic atypical cells. Which of the following is the most likely cancer is this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Squamous cell cancer

 

The presence of hyperchromatic atypical cells on biopsy with the given clinical history suggests a cancer. The history of chronic smoking with hypercalcemia as a paraneoplastic syndrome is a finding of squamous cell cancer (SCC) of the lung.  Hence, the answer is option “b”.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Small cell cancer: Often associated with paraneoplastic syndromes such as SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion) and Cushing's syndrome, not typically hypercalcemia.

 

Option C. Large cell neuroendocrine tumor: Less common, may have neuroendocrine features but not specifically associated with hypercalcemia.

 

Option D. Adenocarcinoma: More common in non-smokers and often presents with peripheral lung lesions. Not typically associated with hypercalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is strongly associated with smoking and can present with hypercalcemia due to ectopic PTHrP production, alongside symptoms such as chronic cough and weight loss.

choices.text: Decreased bearing down efforts by the mother
Cervical Dilatation of 8 cm

questions.text: Ventouse is contra-indicated in? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Preterm

 

Ventouse (vacuum extraction) is contraindicated in preterm deliveries due to the increased risk of neonatal complications. The head of a preterm baby is more vulnerable to injury, and the use of vacuum can lead to severe complications such as neurological damage, cephalohematoma, or skull fractures. This is because the vacuum exerts force on the baby’s head, which is particularly fragile in preterm infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased bearing down efforts by the mother: This is not an absolute contraindication for vacuum delivery. In fact, vacuum extraction is often used when there are decreased maternal efforts during the second stage of labor.

 

Option B. Heart disease: Maternal heart disease is not a contraindication for vacuum extraction. However, it may influence the choice of delivery method to minimize maternal stress.

 

Option D. Cervical Dilatation of 8 cm: While full cervical dilation (10 cm) is ideal for vacuum extraction, it is a relative contraindication rather than an absolute one. In urgent situations where cesarean section is not feasible, vacuum extraction might still be considered even if the cervix is not fully dilated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Absolute Contraindication of Ventouse:

 

  • Preterm
  • Face presentation
  • After coming head of the breech
  • IUD

questions.text:
A patient presents to the emergency department with an unconscious state. An arterial blood analysis reveals the following values:
pH = 7.1; PCO2 = 22 mmHg; HCO3- = 16 mEq/l.

 

Identify the patient’s condition. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metabolic acidosis

 

The patient’s arterial blood analysis shows a pH of 7.1, indicating an acidotic state (normal pH range: 7.35-7.45). The PCO2 is 22 mmHg, which is below the normal range (35-45 mmHg), and the HCO3- is 16 mEq/l, which is also below the normal range (22-28 mEq/l).

 

To determine whether the acidosis is metabolic or respiratory, we look at the bicarbonate (HCO3-) and PCO2 levels. In this case, the decreased HCO3- points towards a metabolic cause. The PCO2 is also low, indicating that the respiratory system is trying to compensate by reducing CO2 levels to counteract the acidosis. Therefore, the primary problem is metabolic acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metabolic alkalosis: This condition would present with an elevated pH (alkalosis) and usually high HCO3- levels, which is not consistent with the provided values.

 

Option C. Respiratory acidosis: This condition would present with an elevated PCO2 and a decreased pH. In this case, the PCO2 is low, not high, ruling out respiratory acidosis.

 

Option D. Respiratory alkalosis: This condition would present with an elevated pH and a decreased PCO2. Although the PCO2 is low, the pH is also low, which is inconsistent with alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of metabolic acidosis, both the pH and bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels are decreased, and the respiratory system may compensate by lowering PCO2.

questions.text: A woman who got IUCD inserted at a PHC, now presents with bleeding. What should be done by the MO? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Iron supplement and observation

 

Bleeding after IUCD (Intrauterine Contraceptive Device) insertion is a common and typically normal physiological response. It is generally expected to subside within the first two menstrual cycles. While reassurance is important, simply reassuring the patient may not be sufficient, as persistent bleeding can lead to anemia.

 

The best approach is to supplement with iron (e.g., ferrous sulfate 200 mg TDS for 8 weeks) to prevent anemia while observing the patient. If the bleeding does not subside despite supplementation, the IUCD may need to be removed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassurance: While reassurance is important, it alone may not be enough if the bleeding persists and leads to anemia.

 

Option B. Remove IUCD: Immediate removal of the IUCD is not the first line of management unless the bleeding persists despite supplementation and observation.

 

Option C. Antibiotics and IV fluids: These are not indicated unless there is an infection or severe bleeding, which is not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron supplementation and observation are crucial in managing post-IUCD insertion bleeding to prevent anemia. If bleeding persists, further action, such as removing the IUCD, may be necessary.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented with chronic low back pain and early morning stiffness since last 2 years, which is also associated with bilateral heel pain. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy.
  • It is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • It also have a variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and peripheral joints.
  • The involvement is an enthesopathy.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis and synovitis.
  • Joints Involved:
    • Primarily affects axial skeleton.
    • The disease usually begins in the sacroiliac joints and usually extends upwards to involve the lumbar, thoracic, and often cervical spine.
    • Hip joint is the most commonly affected peripheral joint.
    • Rarely, knee and ankle are also involved.
       
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years.
    • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, felt deep in lower lumbar or gluteal region, associated with low back morning stiffness of up to few hour duration that improves with activity and returns following period of inactivity.
    • Question mark (?) posture is due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Most serious complication of spinal disease is spinal fracture with even minor trauma.
    • Anterior uveitis: Most common (30%) extra-articular manifestation.
    • Cataract and secondary glaucoma are common sequela.
    • Up to 60% of patients have inflammation of colon or ileum (mostly asymptomatic, only 5-10% develop IBD), 3rd degree heart block, cardiac dysfunction (Aortic incompetence), restrictive lung disease. IgA nephropathy, prostatitis and retroperitoneal fibrosis are other manifestations and may shorten life span.
       
  • Diagnostic criteria – Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these 3
      • Inflammatory back pain if 4/5 are present 
        1. Pain > 3 months
        2. < 40 years of age
        3. Insidious onset
        4. Improves with exercise
        5. Present at night
           
      • Limited chest expansion
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (schober test/modified schober test)
         
  • Spine Radiograph Findings:
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

  • Later on, SI joint show irregular subchondral erosions, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
  • Calcification of supraspinous and interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacro-tuberous ligament.

 

 

Dagger sign (ossification along supraspinous & interspinous ligaments)

  • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons and ligaments.
  • Trolley/tram track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and syndesmophytes are seen. Bamboo spine appearance is due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

A. Trolley track sign (ossification along supraspinous ligaments and facet joints; B. Bamboo spine

 

  • MRI is the most sensitive examination for sacroiliitis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. TB spine. In pott’s spine, the commonest & usually the 1st symptom is back pain, which is usually minimal. Tenderness is the earliest sign. Twist tenderness for Anterior elements is more significant as disease is anteriorly involving the vertebral body (paradiscal). Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When bending forward, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine are in extension (Coin test). Earliest sign in patient with neurological deficit is increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response (twitching of muscles can be seen even earlier). The Earliest X-ray feature is loss of Curvature due to paravertebral spasm. There is reduction of intervertebral disk space and osteoporosis of two adjacent vertebrae, sometimes with fuzziness of the endplates. Paraspinal abscess appears as fusiform shadows along vertebral column.

 

 

Option C. Mechanical back pain. Mechanical back strain is a subtype of back pain where the etiology is the spine, intervertebral discs, or the surrounding soft tissues. Lower back is usually affected the most. More than 80% of people will suffer from low back pain during their lifetime. There is a higher prevalence among women and people ages 40-80 years. Acute mechanical back strains may be triggered by physical or non-physical activity, with lifting being the most commonly recalled event. The patient complaints of axial lumbosacral pain and/or radicular pain into the lower extremity. Low back pain does not necessarily correlate with imaging findings. Plain radiograph is suitable to assess bony abnormalities or fractures.

 

Option D. Prolapsed intervertebral disc. The commonest site of disc prolapse is lumbar spine. In more than 95% of cases lumbar disc herniation are localized at L4-L5 (50% cases) and L5-S1 (45% cases). The next commonest site of intervertebral disc prolapse is lower cervical spine (C5-C6). Lumbar disc is dehydrated hence more prone. Small herniation of nucleus pulposus produce Schmorl’s nodules. Degenerated disc is extruded posteriorly in three patterns: Central, Paracentral (annulus bulges to one side of posterior longitudinal ligament – most common type and produced unilateral radicular symptoms), and Far lateral disc herniation (bulge is within or just lateral to neural foramina).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The described symptoms of chronic low back pain, early morning stiffness, and bilateral heel pain are suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis which involves the enthesis of the body.

questions.text: A patient with history of alcoholism presented with right hypochondriac pain and fever. He had an episode of diarrhoea 1 week prior. USG abdomen reveals a liver abscess of around 25 cc in right lobe. What is the next step in management?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medical management

 

  • This patient with USG revealing abscess in the liver most likely has an amebic liver abscess. Since next best is asked, medical management should be started first.

 

Amoebic liver abscess:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PAIR: PAIR (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, Re-aspiration) is more commonly used for hydatid cysts and not the first-line treatment for amoebic liver abscesses.

 

Option B. Surgery: Surgical intervention is generally reserved for cases where there is no response to medical treatment or complications arise.

 

Option D. Percutaneous drainage: This can be considered if the abscess is large, at risk of rupture, or if there is no response to medical management. However, initial treatment should be medical management with antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For amoebic liver abscess, initial management should always begin with medical therapy using metronidazole, chloroquine, and diloxanide furoate.
  •  Drainage or aspiration is considered based on the size and risk of rupture of the abscess.

questions.text: An Intraoperative image of MRM (Modified Radical Mastectomy) is shown. What nerve is marked? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Median pectoral nerve

 

During a modified radical mastectomy, careful identification and preservation of nerves is crucial to avoid postoperative complications. In this question, the nerve marked runs on the pectoralis minor muscle. This positioning is characteristic of the medial pectoral nerve, which supplies both the pectoralis minor and major muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Long thoracic nerve: This nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle and runs along the chest wall, passing vertically on the serratus anterior muscle, not the pectoralis minor.

 

Option B. Thoracodorsal nerve: This nerve supplies the latissimus dorsi muscle. It is found on the posterior chest wall and runs close to the latissimus dorsi, not along the pectoralis minor.

 

Option D. Subscapular nerve: This nerve innervates muscles such as the subscapularis, teres major, and latissimus dorsi. It is positioned more posteriorly and does not typically run along the pectoralis minor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of a modified radical mastectomy, the medial pectoral nerve runs on the pectoralis minor muscle, distinguishing it from other nerves that are positioned on different muscles in the thoracic region.

questions.text: A factory worker is exposed to phosphine gas during a pesticide fumigation process. He develops nausea, vomiting, dyspnea, and hypotension. Phosphine gas primarily causes which type of hypoxia? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Histotoxic

 

Explanation:

 

Phosphine gas causes histotoxic hypoxia by inhibiting cytochrome oxidase activity in the tissues. This leads to:

 

  • Decreased oxygen uptake by the tissues
  • Reduced mitochondrial function
  • Inability of cells to utilize available oxygen
  • Normal oxygen content in blood but tissues cannot use it
  • Results in cellular hypoxia despite adequate oxygen delivery

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anaemic Hypoxia: Incorrect

 

  • Occurs due to reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of blood
  • Normal alveolar oxygen but reduced hemoglobin or abnormal hemoglobin
  • Examples: Anemia, CO poisoning, methemoglobinemia
  • Not relevant here as phosphine doesn't affect hemoglobin

 

Option B. Hypoxic Hypoxia: Incorrect

 

  • Results from low atmospheric partial pressure of oxygen
  • Reduced oxygen gradient towards alveoli and pulmonary capillaries
  • Examples: High altitude, diffusion disorders, fibrosis
  • Phosphine doesn't affect atmospheric or alveolar oxygen levels

 

Option D. Stagnant Hypoxia: Incorrect

 

  • Due to reduced blood flow/circulation
  • Normal atmospheric oxygen, alveoli, and hemoglobin
  • Occurs in circulatory failure
  • Phosphine primarily affects cellular oxygen utilization, not circulation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phosphine gas causes histotoxic hypoxia by inhibiting cytochrome oxidase in the mitochondria, preventing cellular oxygen utilization despite normal oxygen delivery to tissues.

questions.text: A patient presents with xanthomas on the Achilles tendon. Which of the following is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Familial hypercholesterolemia

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is a genetic disorder characterized by high levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in the blood. A hallmark of this condition is the presence of tendon xanthomas, which are cholesterol deposits typically found in tendons, most commonly in the Achilles tendon. This condition is caused by mutations affecting the LDL receptor or apolipoprotein B, which impair the clearance of LDL from the bloodstream. The Achilles tendon xanthomas are a distinctive feature that helps differentiate familial hypercholesterolemia from other lipid disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tangier's disease: Tangier's disease is characterized by very low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol and the presence of orange-colored tonsils due to the accumulation of cholesterol esters. It does not cause tendon xanthomas, especially on the Achilles tendon, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Familial hyperchylomicronemia: This condition involves elevated triglycerides due to the accumulation of chylomicrons, often leading to eruptive xanthomas rather than tendon xanthomas. It is primarily associated with defects in lipoprotein lipase or apolipoprotein C-II and is not associated with the specific finding of Achilles tendon xanthomas.

 

Option D. Familial Dysbetalipoproteinemia: This condition, associated with a defect in apolipoprotein E, leads to increased levels of both cholesterol and triglycerides, often resulting in palmar xanthomas or tuberous xanthomas, not the specific Achilles tendon xanthomas seen in familial hypercholesterolemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is associated with high LDL cholesterol levels and the presence of tendon xanthomas, particularly on the Achilles tendon

questions.text: Identify the cell marked as X in the given image: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Purkinje cells

 

Explanation: 

 

The image shows a histological section of the cerebellar cortex. The cells marked with X show characteristic features of Purkinje cells:

 

  • They are the largest neurons in the cerebellar cortex
  • Located in the Purkinje layer (between the molecular and granular layers)
  • Organized in a single row
  • Have distinctive large cell bodies and extensive dendritic trees
  • They are the only output cells from the cerebellar cortex

 

Purkinje cells are the only cells that give output from the cerebellum, making them functionally unique and essential for cerebellar function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basket cells: Incorrect 

 

  • Because basket cells are smaller interneurons found in the molecular layer
  • They make connections with Purkinje cell bodies
  • They have a characteristic "basket-like" axonal arborization

 

Option C. Granule cells: Incorrect

 

  • Because granule cells are the smallest and most numerous neurons in the cerebellum
  • They are located in the granular layer (seen as the dense purple layer in the image)
  • They have small round cell bodies

 

Option D. Golgi cells: Incorrect

 

  • Because Golgi cells are interneurons present in the granular layer
  • They are involved in local circuit processing
  • They do not have the characteristic large cell body and location seen in the image

 

Educational Objective:

 

Purkinje cells are the largest neurons in the cerebellar cortex, arranged in a single layer between molecular and granular layers, and serve as the sole output neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

questions.text: Apolipoprotein B 48 is a made of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RNA editing

 

 ApoB-48 is produced through RNA editing. RNA editing involves the modification of the nucleotide sequence of an RNA molecule, specifically the conversion of a cytosine (C) to a uracil (U) in the mRNA. In the case of ApoB-48, this editing changes a codon, resulting in the synthesis of a shorter protein product.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RNA Alternate Splicing: RNA alternate splicing is a process where different exons (coding regions) of a pre-mRNA are combined in various ways to generate different mature mRNA molecules. This process can result in the production of different protein isoforms, but it is not the mechanism for generating ApoB-48.

 

Option C. DNA Editing: DNA editing typically refers to genetic engineering techniques that modify the DNA sequence, such as CRISPR-Cas9. This is not the process by which ApoB-48 is generated.

 

Option D. RNA Interference: RNA interference (RNAi) is a cellular process involved in gene regulation, where small RNA molecules inhibit gene expression. It does not play a direct role in the synthesis of ApoB-48.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In liver cell, Apo B100 gene gives rise to Apo B 100 protein. But Apo B48 protein is made in intestinal cells from the gene encoding Apo B100, by the process of RNA editing, which is also known as Differential RNA processing or chemical modification of RNA. This is a post transcriptional modification.

 

Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 238

questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient is conscious, BP is 90/60 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 40 breaths per minute, and pulse rate is 120 bpm. The X-ray is shown below. What is the next best step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Needle thoracostomy

 

The clinical scenario of an unstable patient and the given X-ray findings, which showing hyperlucent right hemithorax with contralateral mediastinal shift is suggestive of a tension pneumothorax. Inserting a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line followed by a chest tube in the triangle of safety is the best course of action for the management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Pericardiocentesis: This is performed in cases of cardiac tamponade (when presents with beck’s triad), where there is fluid accumulation in the pericardial sac, not applicable here as the X-ray does not suggest this condition.

 

Option. B. Thoracotomy: Indicated for more complex chest injuries or when less invasive procedures fail to resolve the issue. It's a more invasive approach typically reserved for critical cases not resolved by needle thoracostomy or chest tube insertion.

 

Option. D. Chest tube insertion: While ultimately necessary for ongoing management and air evacuation, initial needle thoracostomy is critical to quickly relieve the pressure due to its speed and efficacy in an emergency setting. Chemical pleurodesis, which involves inhaling talc into the chest cavity, is used to achieve pleural adhesion.

choices.text: Loss of sensation on forehead and dorsum of nose
Loss of sensation in jaw area
Loss of sensation in maxillary area of face
Loss of sensation in the mucosa of nasopharynx

questions.text: What will be the clinical presentation if the nerve passing through the marked region has been injured? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of sensation on forehead and dorsum of nose

 

The marked region in the provided images corresponds to the superior orbital fissure, a key anatomical opening through which several cranial nerves pass. Among these, the frontal nerve, a branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve, passes through this fissure. The frontal nerve further divides into the supratrochlear and supraorbital nerves, which supply sensation to the forehead and dorsum of the nose. Injury to this nerve results in loss of sensation in these areas.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Loss of sensation in jaw area: This area is primarily innervated by the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, specifically the inferior alveolar, mental, and buccal nerves, which do not pass through the superior orbital fissure. Therefore, an injury to the nerve passing through the fissure would not affect sensation in the jaw area.

 

Option C. Loss of sensation in maxillary area of face: The maxillary area is innervated by the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve, which exits through the foramen rotundum, not the superior orbital fissure. Thus, injury at the superior orbital fissure would not impact this area.

 

Option D. Loss of sensation in the mucosa of nasopharynx: This region is primarily innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve and branches of the vagus nerve, which do not pass through the superior orbital fissure, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:


The superior orbital fissure allows the passage of nerves that supply sensation to the forehead and dorsum of the nose, including the frontal nerve, whose injury leads to sensory loss in these regions.

questions.text: Which one of the following is related to the release of bicarbonate in exchange of Chloride in the RBC? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chloride shift

 

Explanation: 

 

Chloride shift (also known as Hamburger phenomenon) occurs when RBCs move towards the tissue. As RBCs enter venous blood, CO2 diffuses into them and combines with H2O to form H2CO3 under the influence of carbonic anhydrase. H2CO3 dissociates into H+ and HCO3-. The bicarbonate ion is then exchanged for chloride through an exchanger protein. When chloride enters the RBC, water follows due to osmosis, causing the RBCs to swell. This increases the hematocrit in venous blood compared to arterial blood.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bohr's effect: Incorrect. Because Bohr's effect refers to the right shift of oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve due to increased CO2, decreased pH, or increased temperature, leading to enhanced oxygen unloading in tissues.

 

Option B. Haldane effect: Incorrect. Because Haldane effect describes the enhanced unloading of CO2 in the lungs due to increased oxygenation of hemoglobin. It represents the left shift of the curve in lungs.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect. Because chloride shift is the correct phenomenon describing the exchange of bicarbonate and chloride in RBCs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chloride shift (Hamburger phenomenon) involves the exchange of bicarbonate ions for chloride ions across the RBC membrane during tissue gas exchange, leading to increased RBC volume in venous blood.

questions.text: Laboratory investigations of a patient being evaluated for jaundice show elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels. Levels of the remaining liver enzymes are normal. What is the likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Obstructive jaundice

 

The laboratory findings indicate elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels while other liver enzymes are normal. This pattern is most consistent with obstructive jaundice.

 

In this condition, there is an obstruction in the bile ducts that prevents bile from being excreted into the intestine, leading to an accumulation of conjugated bilirubin in the blood. Alkaline phosphatase is typically elevated in conditions that involve cholestasis (impaired bile flow), which is characteristic of obstructive jaundice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemolytic jaundice: This type of jaundice is caused by the excessive breakdown of red blood cells, leading to elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin. Alkaline phosphatase levels remain normal in hemolytic jaundice.

 

Option C. Hepatic jaundice: Hepatic jaundice occurs due to liver cell damage, which impairs the liver's ability to process and excrete bilirubin. This condition typically shows elevated transaminases (ALT, AST), not just alkaline phosphatase.

 

Option D. Prehepatic jaundice: This term is often used interchangeably with hemolytic jaundice, where the problem lies before the bilirubin reaches the liver. Elevated unconjugated bilirubin and normal alkaline phosphatase levels are seen in prehepatic jaundice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases where laboratory investigations reveal elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase with normal other liver enzymes, obstructive jaundice should be considered as the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: Multidrug-resistant (MDR) TB shows resistance to which of the following drugs? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Isoniazid and rifampicin

 

Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is defined by its resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampicin, which are the two most powerful first-line anti-TB drugs. This resistance makes MDR-TB more difficult and longer to treat than drug-susceptible TB.

 

Isoniazid and rifampicin: These are the cornerstone drugs in the treatment of TB. MDR-TB's resistance to these drugs necessitates the use of second-line medications and a longer, more complex treatment regimen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid, rifampicin, and fluoroquinolone: While resistance to fluoroquinolones can occur, it characterizes pre-extensively drug-resistant (pre-XDR) TB or extensively drug-resistant (XDR) TB, not just MDR-TB.

 

Option B. Fluoroquinolones: Fluoroquinolone resistance typically occurs in more advanced drug-resistant TB cases like pre-XDR and XDR-TB.

 

Option D. Isoniazid, rifampicin, and kanamycin: This option refers to XDR-TB, which includes resistance to at least isoniazid, rifampicin, a fluoroquinolone, and a second-line injectable drug such as kanamycin.

 

Note – Old definition of XDR - H and R resistance plus at least one fluoroquinolone resistance plus at least one second line injectable drug resistance like aminoglycosides (amikacin, kanamycin and capreomycin).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is defined by its resistance to at least isoniazid and rifampicin, the two most important first-line anti-TB drugs.

questions.text: A 18-year-old patient with anasarca is found to have proteinuria of 4.5 g/day, increased cholesterol levels, and hypoalbuminemia. Which of the following is a recommended treatment for this individual? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prednisolone

 

The clinical presentation describes classic nephrotic syndrome, characterized by massive proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia, and increased cholesterol levels. In such cases, especially in younger patients, the initial treatment is prednisolone, an immunosuppressive therapy aimed at reducing podocyte damage. The goal is to control proteinuria and prevent further kidney damage.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Intravenous albumin: Not an effective long-term treatment. Albumin infusion is ineffective because the patient continues to lose albumin through urine, making it a temporary and ultimately futile intervention.

 

Option C. Cyclophosphamide: This is a more aggressive immunosuppressive therapy typically reserved for steroid-resistant or more severe cases of nephrotic syndrome, not as first-line treatment.

 

Option D. Prednisolone and cyclophosphamide: Combination therapy is usually considered only in advanced or treatment-resistant cases, not as initial management for a typical nephrotic syndrome presentation.

 

Educational Objective:


Prednisolone is the first-line immunosuppressive treatment for nephrotic syndrome, particularly in younger patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is the topical local anesthetic used in cataract surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proparacaine 0.5%

 

Proparacaine 0.5% is a topical anesthetic commonly used in cataract surgery. It is favored because it is highly effective when applied in the form of eye drops, providing sufficient anesthesia for superficial surgeries like cataract extraction. Proparacaine has a rapid onset of action, typically anesthetizing the eye within five minutes of application. This quick onset is particularly advantageous for surgeries that are short in duration, such as cataract surgery, which generally lasts between 15 to 30 minutes.

 

Moreover, Proparacaine has minimal systemic absorption, which means it has a lower risk of systemic side effects, making it a safe choice for a wide range of patients. These characteristics make Proparacaine the ideal anesthetic for cataract surgeries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bupivacaine 0.5%: Bupivacaine is a local anesthetic but is typically used for longer procedures or in different forms, such as injections for regional anesthesia. It is not commonly used as a topical anesthetic in eye surgeries due to its longer duration of action and potential for systemic toxicity.

 

Option C. Halothane: Halothane is an inhalational anesthetic, not used as a topical local anesthetic. It is employed for general anesthesia in different surgical contexts, but it is not relevant for cataract surgery.

 

Option D. N₂O (Nitrous Oxide): Nitrous Oxide is also an inhalational anesthetic, primarily used for its analgesic and anesthetic properties in various procedures, but it is not used as a topical anesthetic in eye surgeries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proparacaine 0.5% is the preferred topical anesthetic for cataract surgery due to its rapid onset, appropriate duration of action, and minimal systemic absorption.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with mental retardation and an inability to walk. The fundoscopy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tay-Sachs disease

 

  • The clinical scenario and fundoscopy image suggest the diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease.
  • Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disease caused by the deficiency of hexosaminidase.
  • It presents during infancy with macrocephaly, increased startle reaction, gradual loss of motor skills, and a macular cherry-red spot.
  • Hunter disease is an X-linked disorder that presents with short stature, joint stiffness, and intellectual disability.
  • Hurler syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition that affects multiple organs and presents with corneal clouding, coarse facial features, joint stiffness, skeletal dysplasia, glaucoma, retinal degeneration, and nasal discharge.
  • Gaucher disease is a glycolipid storage disorder that presents with hepatosplenomegaly, mental retardation, and erosion of long bones caused by the deficiency of B-glucosidase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hunter Disease: Hunter disease is an X-linked disorder that presents with short stature, joint stiffness, and intellectual disability. It does not typically present with a cherry-red spot on fundoscopy.

 

Option C. Hurler Syndrome: Hurler syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition that affects multiple organs.

 

  • Presentation:
    • Corneal clouding
    • Coarse facial features
    • Joint stiffness
    • Skeletal dysplasia
    • Glaucoma
    • Retinal degeneration
    • Nasal discharge

 

Option D. Gaucher Disease: Gaucher disease is a glycolipid storage disorder caused by the deficiency of β-glucosidase.

 

  • Presentation:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Mental retardation
    • Erosion of long bones
    • Cherry-red spot may also be seen, but other clinical features and the typical history of Tay-Sachs make it less likely in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tay-Sachs disease presents in infancy with progressive neurological decline, macrocephaly, increased startle reaction, and a characteristic macular cherry-red spot on fundoscopy. It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase A.

 

OTHER CAUSES OF CHERRY RED SPOT.

choices.text: Outer wall contains silica and chlorophyll

questions.text: In a case of drowning, the following organism was isolated from the internal organs. What is true regarding this organism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Outer wall contains silica and chlorophyll

 

The organism in question is a diatom, which is a type of unicellular microscopic algae commonly associated with drowning cases. Diatoms have a distinctive cell wall composed of silica, making them resistant to acidic environments. In drowning cases, if the water containing diatoms enters the body, these organisms can travel through the bloodstream and be found in various organs, including the bone marrow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a unicellular bacteria: This statement is incorrect. Diatoms are unicellular algae, not bacteria. They are distinct in their structure and biological function.

 

Option B.  Not resistant to acid: This statement is incorrect. Diatoms have a silica-based cell wall, which is resistant to acid, allowing them to survive in harsh environments.

 

Option C.  Only present in bone marrow: While diatoms can be found in the bone marrow, especially in cases of drowning, they are not exclusive to this location. They can be distributed to other organs via the circulatory system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diatoms are unicellular algae with a silica-containing outer wall, making them resistant to acid and present in various organs in drowning cases.

questions.text: B-cells are induced to produce IgE by which of the following: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IL-4

 

IL-4 stimulates B-cells to differentiate into IgE secreting plasma cells.

 

IL-4 is a cytokine that plays a crucial role in promoting B-cell differentiation and class switching to produce IgE antibodies. It is primarily produced by T-helper 2 (Th2) cells and stimulates B-cells to undergo isotype switching, leading to the production of IgE instead of other antibody isotypes, such as IgG or IgM.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IL-2:

 

Role: IL-2 is crucial for T-cell proliferation, survival, and activation. It is not directly involved in the induction of IgE production by B-cells.

 

Option C. IL-1:

 

Role: IL-1 is involved in inflammation and immune responses, acting as a pro-inflammatory cytokine. It does not directly induce IgE production.

 

Option D. IL-6:

 

Role: IL-6 is important for inflammation, immune responses, and hematopoiesis. It has roles in the differentiation of B-cells into plasma cells, but it does not specifically induce IgE production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IL-4 is the key cytokine that stimulates B-cells to differentiate into IgE-secreting plasma cells, playing a crucial role in the allergic response and defense against parasites.

questions.text: According to current recommended dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be of total energy intake: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) < 10%

 

According to current dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be <10% of total energy intake.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to current dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be less than 10% of total energy intake.

choices.text: Raised PSV on umbilical artery Doppler
Reduced PSV on umbilical artery Doppler

questions.text: A medical intern is observing an ultrasound for a patient with Rh isoimmunization. Which parameter is used to determine fetal anemia? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Raised PSV on MCA Doppler

 

Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) Peak Systolic Velocity (PSV) is the gold standard non-invasive test for detecting fetal anemia. In fetal anemia, there is increased cardiac output and reduced blood viscosity, leading to faster blood flow. This results in increased PSV in the middle cerebral artery. A PSV value >1.5 MoM (Multiples of Median) for gestational age suggests significant fetal anemia and may indicate the need for further evaluation or intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduced PSV on MCA Doppler: Incorrect because fetal anemia causes increased, not decreased, blood flow velocity in the MCA due to compensatory mechanisms.

 

Option C. Raised PSV on umbilical artery Doppler: While umbilical artery Doppler is useful for assessing placental function and fetal well-being, it is not the primary tool for diagnosing fetal anemia. Changes in umbilical artery flow are more indicative of placental resistance.

 

Option D. Reduced PSV on umbilical artery Doppler: This finding is more associated with placental insufficiency and does not specifically indicate fetal anemia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Increased Peak Systolic Velocity (PSV) in the Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) Doppler is the key non-invasive indicator of fetal anemia.

questions.text: Night blindness history, corneal drying and patient has Bitot’s spots. Which of the following is found in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phrynoderma

 

The symptoms of patient clearly indicate vitamin A deficiency. One of the other clinical feature of vitamin A deficiency is follicular hyperkeratosis aka Phrynoderma which is characterized by excessive keratinization of certain area of body such as elbows and knees. Vitamin A prevents hyperkeratinization.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratosis pilaris rubra: Keratosis pilaris rubra is a skin condition characterized by the appearance of small, red bumps on the skin, often on the arms and thighs. It primarily affects the skin and does not directly relate to the symptoms described.

 

Option B. Eczema: Eczema is a chronic skin condition characterized by red, itchy, and inflamed skin patches. While eczema can affect the skin, it is not associated with night blindness, corneal drying, or Bitot's spots.

 

Option D. Ichthyosis: Ichthyosis is a group of genetic skin disorders that lead to dry, scaly, and thickened skin. It primarily affects the skin's texture and is not commonly associated with night blindness and corneal drying.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Symptoms of night blindness, corneal drying, and Bitot's spots, are indications of vitamin A deficiency. Phrynoderma, which is characterized by goosebump-like skin changes, is a manifestation of severe vitamin A deficiency and is the most relevant option in this context.

 

Ref-Dinesh Puri 3rd e/pg. 393,

questions.text: A truck driver came with complaints of a painless indurated genital ulcer after unsafe intercourse. Motility of the most likely causative organism can be detected by which of the following microscopes? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dark field microscope

 

The clinical vignette of a painless, indurated genital ulcer in a truck driver is most likely suggestive of syphilitic chancre / hard chancre caused by Treponema pallidum. The motility of the organism can be demonstrated by dark ground/ field microscopy.

 

Dark ground microscopy can be used to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present to visualize Treponema pallium. Dark-field microscopy images have a dark background with a refractile organism. The dark ground microscope has an optical system that enhances the contrast of unstained bodies. It is generally less sensitive.

 

Various types of Spirochetes and their appearances under a dark ground microscope:

 

  • Treponemes generally are short, slender with regular and sharp spirals.
  • Leptospira have a large number of closely wound spirals and characteristic hooked ends.
  • Borrelia is large with irregular and wide open coils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Electron microscope: While capable of revealing detailed structures of microorganisms, it is not typically used in clinical settings for diagnosing infections due to its complexity and cost.

 

Option C. Light microscope: Standard light microscopy, typically used with staining techniques, does not easily allow for the visualization of live motility or very thin bacteria like Treponema pallidum.

 

Option D. Fluorescent microscope: Although it can be used to detect specific pathogens if fluorescent-tagged antibodies are available, it is not the standard method for observing motility or diagnosing syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dark field microscopy is essential for observing the motility of Treponema pallidum directly from lesions such as a syphilitic chancre. This diagnostic tool is critical in early stages of syphilis when direct visualization of the pathogen can confirm infection before serological tests become positive.

questions.text: In a case of alcohol abuse, blood during autopsy is preserved in: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sodium fluoride

 

In cases of alcohol abuse, proper preservation of blood during autopsy is crucial for accurate toxicological analysis.
