Sodium fluoride is the preservative of choice for body fluids such as blood, urine, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), and vitreous humor. Sodium fluoride prevents the fermentation of alcohol in the blood sample, ensuring that the alcohol concentration remains stable and can be accurately measured.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rectified spirit: While rectified spirit is used for preserving viscera and is considered the best for that purpose, it is not suitable for preserving blood samples intended for toxicological analysis.

 

Option C. Sodium chloride: Saturated solutions of common salt (sodium chloride) are used for preserving viscera, not blood. They do not prevent fermentation of alcohol in blood samples.

 

Option D. Formalin: Formalin is used for histopathology to preserve tissues. However, it hardens the tissues, making it unsuitable for toxicological analysis as it complicates the extraction of substances like alcohol from the sample.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the preservation of blood/ any body fluids – Sodium fluoride

 

Esp. for Blood – NaF OR Potassium oxalates as anticoagulants    

    

Esp. for Urine – NaF OR Thymol

 

For the preservation of Viscera - Saturated solutions of sodium chloride (MC), Rectified spirit (best to use)

questions.text: Home based urine pregnancy tests detect which hormone? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta hCG

 

Home-based urine pregnancy tests detect human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), specifically the beta subunit of hCG (β-hCG).

 

  • hCG is the earliest detectable hormone in pregnancy
  • hCG is secreted by the trophoblastic cells of the developing placenta soon after implantation, which occurs approximately 6-10 days post-fertilization.
  • The hormone helps maintain the corpus luteum, ensuring continued progesterone production to support early pregnancy.
  • Urine pregnancy tests typically detect hCG levels at or above 20-25 mIU/mL, allowing for early pregnancy confirmation.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone): This is a pituitary hormone involved in follicular development and not specific to pregnancy. It is not used for pregnancy detection as its levels fluctuate throughout the menstrual cycle.

 

Option C. Estrogen: While estrogen levels do increase during pregnancy, it is not specific enough for pregnancy detection as it is also present during normal menstrual cycles.

 

Option D. Progesterone: Although progesterone levels rise during pregnancy, it is not used in home pregnancy tests as it is also present during the luteal phase of menstrual cycles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Home pregnancy tests specifically detect the beta subunit of hCG in urine for pregnancy diagnosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with golden-brown ring over iris on examination. What next is done to diagnose the condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Serum ceruloplasmin

 

This is the most relevant test for the suspected condition. Wilson's disease is a rare inherited disorder that causes copper to accumulate in the liver, brain, and other vital organs. Ceruloplasmin is a protein that binds copper in the bloodstream. In Wilson's disease, serum ceruloplasmin levels are typically low. Testing serum ceruloplasmin is a key diagnostic step for Wilson's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum Iron Level: While important in diagnosing conditions related to iron metabolism such as hemochromatosis or iron-deficiency anemia, serum iron levels are not directly relevant for diagnosing Wilson's disease. Hemochromatosis can also lead to liver damage but doesn't cause Kayser-Fleischer rings.

 

Option C. Alpha-1 Antitrypsin: This test is used to diagnose alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, a genetic condition that can cause lung and liver disease. However, it is not related to the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings and would not be the appropriate next step in this scenario.

 

Option D. Alpha-Fetoprotein: This is a marker often used in the diagnosis of liver cancers, particularly hepatocellular carcinoma. While liver dysfunction is a component of Wilson's disease, alpha-fetoprotein is not a diagnostic marker for Wilson's disease and would not be the best next step in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a patient presents with Kayser-Fleischer rings, it is crucial to evaluate for Wilson's disease, a condition of abnormal copper metabolism. Serum ceruloplasmin is a key diagnostic test in this situation. Understanding the appropriate diagnostic approach for specific clinical signs is essential in guiding effective and efficient patient care.

questions.text: In which type of hysterectomy, is the risk of ureteric injury the least? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vaginal

 

The risk of ureteric injury is least in vaginal hysterectomy compared to other approaches. This is due to the anatomical relationship between the ureter and uterine vessels. The ureter passes underneath the uterine artery (bridge over water concept) approximately 1.5-2 cm lateral to the uterus at the level of the isthmus. When performing a vaginal hysterectomy, the operating field and surgical dissection remains close to the uterus, reducing the risk of encountering and injuring the ureter.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparotomy: Incorrect because in abdominal approach (laparotomy), there is a higher risk of ureteric injury due to wider dissection and direct visualization of the area where ureter crosses under the uterine vessels.

 

Option B. Laparoscopy: Incorrect as laparoscopic approach, despite better visualization, still carries a higher risk of ureteric injury compared to vaginal approach due to the extensive lateral dissection required.

 

Option C. Robotic: Incorrect because robotic approach, similar to laparoscopy, involves lateral pelvic dissection which increases risk of ureteric injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risk of ureteric injury in increasing order is:

 

  • Vaginal hysterectomy (least risk)
  • Abdominal hysterectomy 
  • Laparoscopic hysterectomy
  • Radical hysterectomy (highest)
